subject: Physics - General Physics
Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics
creator: Sivaram, C
Arun, Kenath
title: Charged Black Holes and Constraints on Baryon Asymmetry
description:
The no-hair theorem, which postulates that all black holes can be completely
characterized by only three externally observable parameters: mass, electric
charge, and angular momentum, sets constraints on both the maximal angular
momentum and maximal electric charge. In this work, we would explore the
consequence of these for the formation of primordial black holes in the early
universe and also the formation of black holes due to collapse of dark matter
configurations and how this could be used to probe the conditions in the very
early universe and constrain the epoch when baryon asymmetry was established.

subject: Computer Science - Numerical Analysis
creator: Premjith, B.
Kumar, S. Sachin
Manikkoth, Akhil
Bijeesh, T V
Soman, K P
title: Insight into Primal Augmented Lagrangian Multilplier Method
description:
We provide a simplified form of Primal Augmented Lagrange Multiplier
algorithm. We intend to fill the gap in the steps involved in the mathematical
derivations of the algorithm so that an insight into the algorithm is made. The
experiment is focused to show the reconstruction done using this algorithm.

subject: Quantitative Biology - Neurons and Cognition
creator: Zorikov, Tengiz
title: Echo-processing mechanisms in bottlenose dolphins
description:
The mechanisms of echo-processing were investigated in our experiments,
conducted on bottlenose dolphins. Hierarchically organized system of
independent dimensions, describing echoes in animals perception, was revealed.
The rules of discrimination and recognition of echoes in dolphins were
established.

subject: Computer Science - Neural and Evolutionary Computing
Computer Science - Numerical Analysis
creator: Erdbrink, C. D.
Krzhizhanovskaya, V. V.
Sloot, P. M. A.
title:
Evolutionary Design of Numerical Methods: Generating Finite Difference
  and Integration Schemes by Differential Evolution
description:
Classical and new numerical schemes are generated using evolutionary
computing. Differential Evolution is used to find the coefficients of finite
difference approximations of function derivatives, and of single and multi-step
integration methods. The coefficients are reverse engineered based on samples
from a target function and its derivative used for training. The Runge-Kutta
schemes are trained using the order condition equations. An appealing feature
of the evolutionary method is the low number of model parameters. The
population size, termination criterion and number of training points are
determined in a sensitivity analysis. Computational results show good agreement
between evolved and analytical coefficients. In particular, a new fifth-order
Runge-Kutta scheme is computed which adheres to the order conditions with a sum
of absolute errors of order 10^-14. Execution of the evolved schemes proved the
intended orders of accuracy. The outcome of this study is valuable for future
developments in the design of complex numerical methods that are out of reach
by conventional means.
